subtopics.topic: Solve a Large Percentage of Problems
Reasoning about Graphical Configurations and Communication

subtopics.name: Introduction
subtopics.content: I am now going to introduce a number of fundamental graphs.

subtopics.name: Purpose
subtopics.content: Why do I do that? Because I want to teach you first of all, once you have identified attribute types, what graphs are available to visualize the combination of attributes that you have in your hands.

subtopics.name: Graph Types
subtopics.content: This is a preview of the graphs I'm going to talk about. The bar chart, the scatter plot, the matrix, the line chart and the symbol map.

subtopics.name: Bar Chart
subtopics.content: A type of graph used to represent categorical data with rectangular bars.

subtopics.name: Scatter Plot
subtopics.content: A type of graph used to display the relationship between two continuous variables by showing a set of points on a two-dimensional plane.

subtopics.name: Matrix
subtopics.content: A type of graph used to show the relationship between two or more variables using a matrix of cells, where the cells are colored or shaded based on the value of the variable.

subtopics.name: Line Chart
subtopics.content: A type of graph used to display changes in data over time by connecting a series of data points with a line.

subtopics.name: Symbol Map
subtopics.content: A type of graph used to represent data on a map, where the data is displayed using symbols, such as circles or squares, that vary in size, color, or shape based on the value of the data.

subtopics.name: Reasons for Using These Graphs
subtopics.content: There are a number of reasons but most importantly because they are widely adopted, they are very effective and they are very useful. A second reason is that they solve a very large percentage of visualization problems. It's really surprising how many problems out there can be solved by one of these five graphs or variants over these graphs.

subtopics.name: Training Ground
subtopics.content: These graphs are an amazing training ground before you are able to discuss and design more sophisticated graphs. So, I find that they are from the pedagogical standpoint extremely useful.

subtopics.name: Combinations of Attributes
subtopics.content: The graphs that I'm going to show you can all be described as combinations of two or sometimes three attributes.
